{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Hey, what's on your mind today?", 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:41:42.545769+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_e4cb976e8f6030021501e4fd943ee617c753012b9aa7bfa60cb8b7f32a6bb1c427d63a0a52aab272d47753ccba02f6d9', 'size_bytes': 91278, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 1.9}}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "I was wondering if there's a way to align Joe Edelman's value perspective on CAPs and IAPs, so Constitutive Intentional Policies and Instrumental Intentional Policies, and to realize, like, the gaps. I've been thinking about how Joe Edelman realizes or, like, describes CAPs, or Constitutive Intentional Policies, as a list of, you know, sources of meaning, although implies that they are sort of not comprehensive, but kind of grasping at a sense of synergy, but also at the same breath, while calling them non-instrumental, says that they are, you know, kind of taken on as policies for assumed benefits, and that they might actually just be a shorthand for talking about, like, yeah, it's kind of good, I think, to live like this, I think this is the right way, and then, you know, it's either validated or not, I guess, I'm not really sure, but, like, I kind of feel like there's an issue here in his definition, and I'm wondering if you can help me see if other people have found this, like, problematic definition, and kind of how to undo it, or how to clarify his work even further.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:44:18.871506+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:44:18.871506+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_3004ec4312f4300223c9a26d354cb799c753012b9aa7bfa60cb8b7f32a6bb1c427d63a0a52aab272d47753ccba02f6d9', 'size_bytes': 4783278, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 99.65}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 109.51504539698362}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "I'd like you to help me think about it yourself, like, what are sources of meaning and attentional policies? Like, how does one determine an attentional policy?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:45:07.185690+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:45:07.185690+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_7da64653d6a8300224fc19ddf79d8ccfc753012b9aa7bfa60cb8b7f32a6bb1c427d63a0a52aab272d47753ccba02f6d9', 'size_bytes': 726798, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 15.14}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 179.75573524460196}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, I think kind of the whole problem is the want part, right? Like, how do you choose? It seems kind of arbitrary to kind of like pick some policies that you want, or you think are like, oh, this is cool. It's like you do, let's live like this. This sounds good. But like, what does it want?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'That\'s a great point. Defining what you "want" can indeed feel arbitrary. It often comes down to deeper reflection on your core values and what resonates with you. Wants can be rooted in your experiences, beliefs, or even a sense of purpose. They\'re not always logical or linear, but they often align with what gives your life meaning or fulfillment. \n\nA "want" can be seen as an expression of what you find valuable or important. It might feel arbitrary, but it\'s often influenced by your unique perspective, experiences, and aspirations. Exploring these can help clarify your intentional policies and create a more coherent path forward.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}

{'expiry_datetime': '2025-02-19T15:46:25.952052+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_c04b51aa7eb430023ee3a4e2c6519bfac753012b9aa7bfa60cb8b7f32a6bb1c427d63a0a52aab272d47753ccba02f6d9', 'size_bytes': 12078, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 0.25}}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "The attentional policy is being kind of what we're drawn to naturally during a meaningful moment. And so we have a thing to kind of, you know, determine or gauge. And it kind of already is like leading to this perspective that you can look at yourself looking at yourself, and it really has this sort of meta-cognitive perspective or this idea of who is the real witnesser anyway perspective, although it doesn't take it or explicate it or even point out that that's what he's doing. He's like, what are you paying attention to in a moment of meaning, right? And like, what are you attending to? And it's true, like, you can't really do both at the same time, right? Like in the moment of meaning, especially if it's a powerful moment of meaning, you're just in it, you know, you're a part of the soup. But when you can step away, you can kind of look at yourself and say, oh, yeah, what really matters to me is how I was noticing X, Y, or Z. And I think that's kind of an interesting thing to kind of like check in with somehow. And what do you think that these kinds of things can bring to our discussion about moments of meaning and the idea of understanding what is actually meaningful for somebody that isn't just kind of arbitrary? Like, where does it come from? Like, why do you think attention goes this way or that way during different moments? And how does it differ from person to person? Like, would different people have different things that are meaningful for them? I mean, people that make movies, right? Like, they're trying to get something that strikes an emotional chord with a broad audience, you know? So what is that?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
